_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary

This document has been prepared to demonstrate how Supreme Oil, complies with the requirements set forth under EPA's Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68).



It specifically addresses the requirements applicable to the use of anhydrous ammonia at Supreme Oil.  The following sections provides a general overview of the requirements and defines the design attributes, documentation, and actions that are established to comply with those requirements.  This summary provides a cross-reference to the applicable existing documentation.  



1.1.    Commitment to Safety

Supreme Oil is committed in providing to all employees a work environment that is free from recognized health and safety hazards. Accordingly, our goal is achieving and sustaining "Zero Accident Tolerance" through communication, information, and training. To this end, we are dedicated to the concept that all employees receive the proper orientation and are provided with the means necessary to ensure the environment remains as safe and healthful as possible.



1.1.1.    It is the policy of Supreme Oil to: 

1.1.1.1.    Provide safe working conditions, proper tools, and personal protective equipment.

1.1.1.2.    Comply with all federal, state, and local occupational Health and Safety laws and regulations.

1.1.1.3.    Provide and sustain a high level of commitment to ensure all employees have a safe and healthy work environment in which to work.

1.1.1.4.    Ensure, through training, and when necessary disciplinary action, that all employees work in a safe manner.  Educate and/or train all employees in safe work practices, and ensures that each employee fully understands his or her job, equipment, techniques, and methods to reduce the risk to himself or herself and their co-workers.

1.1.2.    Encourage all employees to "Think Safety", so that safety habits developed and practiced at work carry through to non-work related activities.

1.1.3.    This facility's aim is to provide a professio

nal service as efficiently as possible while minimizing the use of toxic materials wherever and whenever prudent. In this effort our highest priority will be the proactive pursuit of cost-effective process changes that reduce or eliminate the use and/ or generation of hazardous toxics at the endpoint of service. Where hazardous toxics cannot be eliminated, improving controls to handle these substances will be explored and implemented wherever possible.

1.1.4.    Supreme Oil has prepared a facility safety policy and procedures program specifically tailored for the facility. In addition, a Process Safety Management Program has also been established regarding the ammonia process. It is the responsibility of designated facility personnel to carry out these programs.

1.1.5.    The first duty of Supreme Oil employees is to exercise care in the performance of his/her work tasks to prevent an accident to him/her, co-workers, the general public or equipment. Safety-consciousness must take precedence over expedience, and is required as a condition of continued employment of all employees at all levels of the organization. 



1.2.    Facility Description

Supreme Oil is an edible oils, mayonnaise, salad dressings, and condiments processing facility; where food ingredients are received, blended, mixed, cooked, packaged and boxed for shipment to end users. There are approximately 130 employees working at the facility.

1.2.1.    The substance regulated under the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) located on site, in various locations and quantities is anhydrous ammonia.

1.2.2.    Anhydrous Ammonia is utilized on site for the "Process System".  Approximately 13,800 pounds of ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the system. The ammonia is contained in various vessels, cooling units, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the Process System. The facility compressor room houses the compressors.

1.2.3.    The high pressure receiver, glycol chillers and condensers a

re located in an area outside the building behind the maintenance department on the west side of the facility.



1.3.    Emergency Response Program 

1.3.1.    Supreme Oil is equipped with an emergency information system.

1.3.1.1.    Evacuation plans are placed throughout the facility to inform personnel in an emergency relating to the accidental release of ammonia, or other emergencies that may be encountered.



There are specific procedures that all employees must follow in the event of a release; which can be found in the Supreme Oil Emergency Action Plan. These procedures include evacuation of personnel, notification of authorities and actions to be taken to stop, or mitigate the emergency if it is safe to do so.



Plant personnel have received emergency response training as outlined in OSHA's HAZWOPER regulation 29 CFR 1910.120.

1.3.1.2.    Supreme Oil is willing to work with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Area Fire Department to ensure understanding of the Process operations, safety systems and discuss emergency Response coordination.



2. Management

2.1.    Under EPA's 40 CFR 68.15, the facility is required to assign a qualified person with overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and documentation of a system to manage the Risk Management Program elements.

2.2.    Consistent with OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM), the facility's Plant Manager, Richard Grasser, has overall responsibility for program implementation and management, with support from the Supreme Oil employee staff.



3. Release Prevention Program 

3.1.    Process Safety Information

3.1.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.65, the facility is required to complete written data regarding process safety information before conducting any process hazard analysis. This compilation aids in the identification and understanding of the hazards posed by processes involving regulated substances.

3.1.1.1.    Personal Exposure Limits (PELs) and physical and chemical characteristics, reactivity, and

corrosivity can be found in the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS), located in the Process Safety Information Procedure. Thermal and chemical stability, and compatibility with other chemicals are also addressed in the MSDS.

3.1.1.2.    A block flow diagram of the process is on file in the engineering department office.

3.1.1.3.    The process system used at Supreme Oil is an enclosed loop mechanical process system that utilized anhydrous ammonia as a heat exchange media in the processing of the refrigerated food products. There are no chemical reactions involving ammonia that occur. The principle involved is the ability of a refrigerant, in this case ammonia, to absorb heat as it changes state from a liquid to a gas, and to give up that heat as it changes back to a liquid. The compressors supply the change in pressure levels required to accomplish this.

3.1.1.4.    The heat is absorbed in the cooling evaporators of various designs, and removed from the system by the condensers. More detailed and specific descriptions of the process system are provided in the PSM files.

3.1.1.5.    The process system is charged with 13,800 pounds of anhydrous ammonia to achieve the proper operating pressures and levels that are required within the Process system.

3.1.1.6.    The safe upper and lower temperatures, pressures, flows and compositions are addressed in the Operating Procedures. The consequences of deviating from these safe limits are also addressed in the Operating Procedures as well as the Process Hazard Analysis. 

3.1.1.7.    The Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&IDs) are located in the engineering department office while the electrical classification, ventilation design, and pressure relief system design are documented in Process Safety Information Procedure.

3.1.1.8.    The primary safety system consists of pressure relief valves located on the system's pressure vessels. The relief valves will vent to atmosphere in the event of an overpressure situation within the vessel or asso

ciated process components.

3.1.1.9.    In addition to the pressure relief valves, there are high-level shutdown devices configured to various pressure vessels within the process, which will shut down compressor operation in the event of an abnormal operating level in the process system vessel.

3.1.1.10.    The compressor room and processing areas of the facility are equipped with ammonia detection sensors that activate alarms and ventilation fans in the event a pre-determined level of ammonia is released.

3.1.1.11.    There is a Switch or "King Valve" located outside the compressor room exit that will shutdown the entire process system if activated by facility personnel.



3.2.    Process Hazard Analysis

3.2.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.67, Supreme Oil is required to perform an initial process hazard analysis on processes involving regulated substances. The analysis is required to identify, evaluate, and control the hazard involved in the process.

3.2.2.    There have been no previous incidents associated ammonia at the Supreme Oil

3.2.3.    The hazards of the process are identified in Process Safety Information.  Safeguards to control hazards and prevent malfunctions and errors are identified in the Process Hazard Analysis.

3.2.4.    The consequences of system failures are addressed in the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA).  

3.2.5.    The findings and recommendations of the PHA team can be found in the PHA files. The owner/operator's response to the PHA findings, along with the schedule of response action implementation and documentation of the implementation, is also addressed in the PHA Files.

3.2.5.1.    PHA's are performed as required by the PSM/RM program, or revalidated at least once every 5 years.

3.2.5.2.    All PHA documentation is retained for the life of the process.



3.3.    Operating Procedures 

3.3.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.69, Supreme Oil is required to develop and implement written operating procedures for safety conducting activities on processes involving regulated substances.

3.3.2.

Written procedures, precautions, and parameters for the safe operation, shutdown, and maintenance of the system are addressed in the Operating Procedures.

3.3.3.    Procedures for start-up, temporary operations, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown are included in the Operating Procedures.

3.3.4.    Operating limits, consequences of deviation, and steps required to correct or avoid deviation are addressed in the Operating Procedures.



3.4.    Training

3.4.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.71, the Facility is required to provide training to employees operating processes involving regulated substances.

3.4.2.    All employees received initial training as described Training Procedure, and will be followed by refresher training a minimum of once every three years.  Employees will receive continual on the-job training regarding understanding hazards, operating procedures, maintenance, and inspection.

3.4.2.1.    Sign-in sheets, verification of understanding and documentation of the Training for each employee are located in the safety office files.



3.5.    Mechanical Integrity/Maintenance

3.5.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.73, Supreme Oil is required to establish and implement written procedures to maintain the ongoing integrity of process equipment, to provide training to employees regarding these procedures, and to provide for testing and inspection of process equipment.    

3.5.2.    Procedures for testing, inspection and preventative maintenance are in the Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

3.5.3.    Documentation of maintenance activities is maintained on file within the facility's computerized maintenance management system (CMMS).



3.6.    Management of Change

3.6.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.75, Supreme Oil is required to establish and implement written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.   

3.6.2.    Written procedures to manage changes and requirements for training personnel when changes occur, or when Standard Operating Procedures or Standard Maintenance

Procedures are updated, are located in the Management of Change Procedure.



3.7.    Compliance Audits

3.7.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.79, Supreme Oil is required to certify that the procedures and practices developed under this standard have been evaluated at least every 3 years and that they are adequate and are being followed.

3.7.2.    An audit to evaluate facility compliance within the requirements of this program will be completed every 3 years.

3.7.3.    Documentation of findings, responses, and corrective actions resulting from the completion of the PSM audit checklist shall be added into the PSM Files.

3.7.4.    The two most recent audit reports will be maintained the PSM Files.



3.8.    Incident Investigation

3.8.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.81, Supreme Oil is required to investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.    

3.8.2.    Within 48 hours of each incident that results in, or could have resulted in, a "catastrophic release" of ammonia, an investigation shall be initiated into the incident in accordance with the Emergency Action Plan.



3.9.    Employee Participation

3.9.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.83, Supreme Oil is required to develop a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation.

3.9.2.    A written plan of action for employee participation in Process Hazard Analysis, Management of Change, and training is included in the Employee Participation Procedure.

3.9.3.    Access to documents is also addressed in the Employee Participation Procedure.



3.10.    Hot Work Permits

3.10.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.85, Supreme Oil is required to issue hot work permits for hot work conducted on or near a covered process.

3.10.2.    Hot work permits shall be issued in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.252(a), and as described in the PSM Standard 1910.119(k).



3.11.    Contractor Program

3.11.1.    Responsibilities of the facility and of contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovations

, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process are specified under 40 CFR 68.87. This section does not apply to contractors providing incidental service that do not influence process safety, such as janitorial work or food services.

3.11.2.    Supreme Oil personnel shall evaluate the safety performance and safety programs of contractors during the selection process, in accordance with guidelines in the Contractor Safety Procedure.

3.11.3.    Supreme Oil shall provide hazard information and emergency response procedures to all contractors prior to their entering the facility to commence work. 

3.11.4.    Contractors shall receive an annual performance evaluation regarding the fulfillment of their obligations, including:

3.11.4.1.    Each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job.

3.11.4.2.    Each contract employee is instructed in the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to his/her job and the process, and the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.  

3.11.5.    The contractor has documented that each contract employee has received and understood the required training. Documentation to be maintained by the contractor shall Include the employee's name, date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

3.11.6.    Each contract employee follows applicable facility safe work practices.

3.11.7.    The contractor will notify Supreme Oil management staff of any unique hazards presented by the contractor's work or any hazards found by the contractor's work.



4. Accident History

Supreme Oil has had no reportable accidents associated with anhydrous ammonia.

Supreme Oil performs an incident investigations on all accidents even if they are below the reportable quantity (100lbs of ammonia). 



5. Emergency Response Program

5.1.    Under 40 CFR 68.95, the facility is required to develop and implement an emergency response program for the purpose of protect

ing public health and the environment.  

5.2.    Supreme Oil technicians have received training as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.120. Their objective is to provide emergency response applications on any hazardous/toxic substance release and follow emergency procedures that provide for safe shut down. Qualified Supreme Oil technicians receive annual refresher training as required by 29 CFR 19.120.

5.3.    Procedures for notifying the local emergency response agencies of accidental releases are detailed in the facility Emergency Plan. 

5.4.    Documentation of emergency medical procedures to treat accidental Human exposures is included in the Emergency Plan as well as the Process Safety Information and Operating Procedures.



6. Planned Improvement

6.1.    In an effort for continuous improvement, Supreme Oil plans to improve:

6.1.1.    Communication and training with existing and new employees.

6.1.2.    Review and improve procedures.

6.1.3.    Enhance the communication and involvement with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Area Fire Department.
